Key Arguments: The bill threatens Australian democracy and human rights by potentially ending free speech.
It grants excessive power to the government, making it the ultimate authority on truth.
The definitions of 'misinformation' and 'disinformation' are too broad and subjective.
The bill could lead to censorship of journalists and ordinary Australians.
There is a lack of accountability and transparency in how the powers would be exercised.
The bill is compared to oppressive regimes, such as the Soviet Union.
It is inconsistent with international human rights obligations.
Penalties for non-compliance are excessive and could limit free speech.
Notable Quotes: This bill is a threat to Australian democracy and human rights, will mark an end to free speech in Australia and will significantly limit government accountability.
The bill could lead to censorship of journalists and ordinary Australians.
I cannot help but draw a comparison between what will happen in Australia under this bill and what was happening in the Soviet Union under the communist regime.
